awd_titl_txt: RET Site: Research Experiences for Teachers in Neural Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The 3-year NSF RET site on Neural Engineering at University of Missouri-Columbia (MU) focuses on the rapidly growing field of neural engineering that aims to address the global challenge of not only understanding the functioning of normal and pathological brains, but also devising approaches to address neurological limitations and dysfunction. The field requires a workforce trained across the physical and life sciences, and such training should begin at the K-12 level by incorporating engineering approaches, including the use of models, into STEM education. 

A multidisciplinary MU team with neuroscience faculty from Engineering, Biology, Psychology and Medicine, will host 10 teachers/year spanning all grades, for a 6-week duration during the summer, from primarily rural districts around Columbia, MO.  The goal will be to recruit 90% of the teachers from rural or Title-1 schools. Teachers will spend the majority of the 6-week period in relevant labs engaging in research activities under the mentorship of a professor and graduate students. The program will increase research competency of teachers in core neuroscience concepts and in engineering approaches, that are linked to national education and technology standards, respectively. Teachers will work on neural engineering projects and will develop curricula for K-12 classrooms. In addition to research skills, during weekly classes, teachers will also learn modern technological tools that will influence their classroom teaching. They will also explore the neurobiological underpinnings of learning and its link to improving student experience via group readings from an influential book "Make it Stick" providing a common scientific theme unifying the seemingly diverse neural research projects for the teacher. Year-long follow up will focus on assisting teachers with their needs including incorporating engineering approaches, curricular modules and technological tools into their classrooms, and with planning their conference presentations.  The curricular modules developed by the RET program teachers will be submitted to the NSF-supported peer-reviewed portal TeachEngineering.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF OUR NSF REU SITE ON NEURAL ENGINEERING:

(i) Recruit K-12 STEM teachers from rural schools that normally have smaller budgets and limited access to resources and professional STEM development; our goal will be to recruit 90% of the teachers from rural or Title-1 schools, especially those with low income and high mobility rates;

(ii) Increase research competency of teachers in core neuroscience concepts, which is relevant to and also unifies the seemingly diverse neural engineering research projects (across intracellular/ cellular, systems and behavioral levels). Additionally, increase competency in interdisciplinary engineering approaches, in the usage of modern technological tools, and in the development of curricular modules for submission to an NSF-supported portal; all of which can be translated back into the classroom;

(iii) Create a cohort experience for teachers to facilitate successful research and curricular experiences, by weekly classes where, in addition to the topics above, the neurobiological underpinning of learning and its link to student experience will also be emphasized via a book reading.

KEY OUTCOMES

1.  Training of 29 RET Teacher Fellows from diverse disciplines and grades, split across the three years as follows:  

Year 1 (2019): 10 Teacher Fellows (3 elementary, 3 middle and 4 high school). 100% of the teachers were from rural and/or title-1 schools, with 5 from schools that were both rural as well as title-1. Their split across school levels were as follows: High school - 4 Biology + Middle school – 3 Science, and Elementary - 3 Science teachers. Demographics: 8 were females, 2 males; All were White/Caucasian and all from rural and/or title-1 schools.

Year 2 (2023): 5 Teacher Fellows (2 elementary, 1 middle and 2 high school level). 100% of the teachers were from rural and/or title-1 schools, with 4 from schools that were both rural as well as title-1. Their split across school levels were as follows: High school - 2 Biology + Middle school – Science, and Elementary - 2 science teachers. Demographics: 4 were females, 1 male; 4 were White/Caucasian and 1 African American (female).

Year 3 (2024): 14 Teacher Fellows (2 elementary and 13 high school level). They were from 3 satellite programs around the nation (Missouri, Chicago-Illinois, and Manhattan-New York). The 2 elementary teachers were from rural and/or title-1 schools, and 2 of the high school teachers were from inner-city title-1 schools. Their split across school levels were as follows: High school - 6 Biology, 1 Chemistry, 3 Computer Science, and 2 Engineering + 2 elementary science teachers. Demographics: 9 were females, 5 males; Of these, 7 were White/Caucasian, 2 African-American, 1 Hispanic, 1 Middle-Eastern, and 3 Asian.

________

2.  We had excellent training outcomes on the publication process also: 2 high school teacher posters at the Neuroscience 2024, Annual International Meeting of the Society for Neuroscience; + a surprisingly significant 25 design activity submissions to the NSF-supported peer-reviewed portal TeachEngineering.org: 2 published; 6 awaiting publication; 6 in review + 11 in preparation.

3.  Introduction of a novel ‘satellite’ program post-covid, during Year 2, that was fully developed during Year 3. This was a huge accomplishment, and is a potentially innovative and transportable model across the nation, particularly to reach interested/motivated teachers in far-flung title-1 and rural schools.

4.  The program was unique in the fact that neuroscience covers several levels of inquiry from genetic to molecular, cellular, systems, behavioral and clinical levels. For teachers, this provides a unique interdisciplinary training ground to learn about the advances in the problem- and data- rich and growing area of neuroscience. Such an interdisciplinary-training is very beneficial for them since they impact numerous students in their classrooms, causing a huge multiplier effect.

5.  Finally, the program helped strengthened competency in several areas for the 29 teachers during the 3-year project, which will continue to impact students they teach: 

-    Engineering approaches in curriculum via development of lesson plans using TeachEngineering.org templates for teacher-driven lesson plans. The process also reinforced engineering and technology standards, including in growing area of neural engineering.

-    Appreciation for research and relevant skills via research projects in neural engineering.

-    Coding and math skills of all teachers via instruction and exercises in both topics (they were required to complete), using the popular $15 micro:bit computer (microbit.org)

-    Pedagogy skills using the book read ‘Make it Stick’ which includes latest findings from cognitive neuroscience and cognitive psychology, which are also relevant to neuroscience

-    Appreciation for the growing area of neural science and engineering design concepts which are now part of the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) for the K-12 curriculum

-    Technological skills related to interfacing micro:bit, EMG sensors, etc. using python (most projects during Year 3). And in integrating them into curricular modules, that include an appreciation for ‘engineering design’ as outlined at TeachEngineering.org.
